name: tua_phidu_2015_lga_aust_risk_factors_adults_2014_15
title: LGA15 Adults Health Risk Factor Estimates - 2014-2015

legal.licenceType: Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Australia (CC BY-NC-SA 3.0 AU)

keyword: adult,tua,smoking,torrens university australia,phidu,weight,public health information development unit,health risk factors adults,blood pressure,health risks,alcohol,psychological distress,excercise,fruit intake
abstract:
Estimated number of males/females/people aged 18 years and over whose health was at risk in one of the following categories: psychologically distressed, blood pressure, overweight, obesity, waist measurement, smoking, alcohol consumption, fruit consumption and no or low exercise, 2014-15 (all entries that were classified as not shown, not published or not applicable were assigned a null value; no data was provided for Maralinga Tjarutja LGA, in South Australia). The data is by LGA 2015 profile (based on the LGA 2011 geographic boundaries). For more information on statistics used please refer to the PHIDU website, available from: http://phidu.torrens.edu.au/.
Source: Estimates for Population Health Areas (PHAs) are modelled estimates and were produced by the ABS; estimates at the LGA and PHN level were derived from the PHA estimates.

selectedAttributes.name: hbld_pres_2_asr
selectedAttributes.title: Estimated number of people with high blood pressure ? ASR per 100 population
selectedAttributes.description: The estimated number of people aged 18 years and over who had high blood pressure, 2014-15 ? Indirectly age-standardised rate per 100 population (Indirectly age-standardised refers to adjustments made through comparisons against the relevant standard Australian population).

selectedAttributes.name: lw_excse_2_asr
selectedAttributes.title: Estimated number of people who did low or no exercise ? ASR per 100 population
selectedAttributes.description: The estimated number of people aged 18 years and over did low (score less than 800) or no exercise in the week prior to the survey, exercise was calculated by duration (minutes) X intensity factor (walking for fitness = 3.5, moderate = 5, vigorous = 7.5), 2014-15 ? Indirectly age-standardised rate per 100 population (Indirectly age-standardised refers to adjustments made through comparisons against the relevant standard Australian population).

selectedAttributes.name: obese_p_4_asr_uci
selectedAttributes.title: Estimated number of obese people ? ASR per 100 population ? upper confidence interval
selectedAttributes.description: The estimated number of people aged 18 years and over who were obese based on their Body Mass Index BMI (30 or greater), 2014-15 ? Indirectly age-standardised rate per 100 population ? upper 95 percent confidence interval.

selectedAttributes.name: ovrwgt_p_3_asr_lci
selectedAttributes.title: Estimated number of overweight people ? ASR per 100 population ? lower confidence interval
selectedAttributes.description: The estimated number of people aged 18 years and over who were overweight (but not obese) based on their Body Mass Index BMI (between 25 and 30), 2014-15 ? Indirectly age-standardised rate per 100 population ? lower 95 percent confidence interval.

selectedAttributes.name: psych_dstrs_4_asr_uci
selectedAttributes.title: Estimated number of people with psychological distress ? ASR per 100 population ? upper confidence interval
selectedAttributes.description: The estimated number of people aged 18 years or over with ?high? (scores of 22-29); and ?very high? (scores of 30-50) psychological distress based on the Kessler 10 Scale (K10), 2014?15 ? Indirectly age-standardised rate per 100 population ? upper 95 percent confidence interval.

selectedAttributes.name: wst_meas_p_3_asr_lci
selectedAttributes.title: Estimated number of people with a high risk waist measurement ? ASR per 100 population ? lower confidence interval
selectedAttributes.description: The estimated number of people aged 18 years and over with a waist measurement of 94cm or more for men or 80cm or more for women, which indicates increased risk of developing chronic disease, 2014-15 ? Indirectly age-standardised rate per 100 population ? lower 95 percent confidence interval.
